Name: Printer Matter
Description: Largest store dedicated to zines I've come across in NYC.

Name: Hauser & Wirth
Description: The W 18th St location has a bar, gallery space, and bookstore with a curated selection ranging from mainstream bestsellers to more niche publications.

Name: The Drama Book Shop
Description: Theater and film-focused bookstore that stocks play scripts as well. Not exactly my cup of tea but bring your thespian friends here.

Name: Rizzoli Bookstore
Description: They have a myriad of photobooks and frequent author talks.

Name: Mercer Street Books & Records
Description: Compact shop filled with used books at affordable prices. I was able to find some good titles in my favorite genres.

Name: Fishs Eddy
Description: All sorts of funky kitchenware can be found - some more affordable than others. Fishs Eddy also has unique NYC-themed items that would make for great souvenir gifts.

Name: Gothic Renaissance
Description: Came here because my friend was looking for medieval-inspired outfits (I may be mixing my time periods together) but their clothing is super cool to look at.

Name: Bungee Space
Description: Lots of underground publications and Chinese zines. Also large selection of streetwear clothes in the back. Many things to stop and look at inside.

Name: Mighty Lucky
Description: I laughed when I first walked inside because it's literally a concept store of someone's favorite things. They sell plants, tabletop art pieces, and is also a legal cannabis dispensary.

Name: Philip Williams Posters
Description: Vintage posters and prints ranging from postcard-sized to full-wall hangings.

Name: Pageant Print Shop
Description: I stumbled across this place by accident and was pleasantly suprised by their large selection of nature and map-themed prints.

Name: Archie's Press
Description: Unique prints and posters - you'll find a lot of their stuff at various flea and craft markets.

Name: Toy Tokyo
Description: Tightly-packed with blind boxes and anime trinkets.

Name: Sweet Pickle Books
Description: Exchange your books for pickles!

Name: Mociun Fine Jewelry & Home Goods
Description: Very interesting home decor pieces ... in particular they seem to specialize in realistic-looking food pieces.

Name: ACRE
Description: It's a food hall in the back but a tiny little shop in the front selling Japanese ceramic goods and kitchenware.

Name: Souvenir
Description: Classic modern tchotchkes shop. Great for finding specific gifts for specific friends.

Name: Tula House
Description: Beautiful plant store with gorgeous interior.

Name: Million Goods
Description: Wine bar, music, and clothing - another brainchild of someone's favorite things. If I were a man I'd buy all the clothes here for my wardrobe.

Name: Yoseka Stationery
Description: Japanese stationary store.

Name: Wilcoxson Brooklyn Ceramics
Description: Pricey but spunky ceramic cups and bowls.

Name: Word
Description: Bookstore.

Name: Lockwood Greenpoint
Description: I got a green skirt I really liked from here. Gift shop with clothing, NYC-themed trinkets, and toys.

Name: Secret Riso Club
Description: One-of-a-kind zines and prints. I really want to attend one of their risograph workshops. Thanks to Annie for sharing this place.

Name: Hive Mind Bookstore
Description: Coffee shop + bookstore combo; large selection of queer and feminist literature.

Name: Honey Moon Coffee Shop
Description: Coffee shop + bookstore combo.

Name: Lichen
Description: Furniture and interior design store.

Name: Left Field NYC
Description: Men's workwear - I got a cool t-shirt from here.

Name: Topos Bookstore Cafe
Description: Coffee shop + bookstore combo.

Name: Saint Seneca Store
Description: Minimalist concept store.

Name: usagi
Description: Art gallery + cafe + bookstore. When I went they were displaying artwork from a famous anime illustrator.

Name: Outside Space Garden Center
Description: I randomly wandered here out of curiosity and found a lovely garden as a respite from the busy city streets. It's a plant nursery.

Name: Greenlight Bookstore
Description: Bookstore.

Name: BLOK HAUS
Description: Plants.

Name: Remix Market NYC
Description: Thrift store for furniture and home decor.

Name: Astoria Bookshop
Description: Bookstore.

Name: Scorpion Records
Description: Record Store.

Name: East Broadway Mall
Description: Go to the second floor to find all the alternative thrift stores for trust fund babies.

Name: FGS Outpost
Description: I only popped in for a quick second but my interpretation is that it's a minimalist concept shop.

Name: Yu & Me Books
Description: Bookstore.

Name: Bluestockings Cooperative Bookstore
Description: Bookstore. Very progressive selection of books.

Name: Hammock Grove
Description: Mmm... lots of hammocks to nap in. Take the free ferry to Governor's Island.

Name: Pier 2 Swings
Description: Go swinging rain or shine with a cool backdrop of NYC.

Name: POWERHOUSE @ IC
Description: Bookstore.

Name: Sunset Park
Description: My favorite park in NYC; come here during the summer at sunset for an experience you won't forget.

Name: Martha P. Johnson Park
Description: I think this is the most underrated waterfront park - sit on the grass and you'll have a view of both the river and the city skyline.

Name: Gantry Plaza
Description: There's two willow trees at this spot that reminds me of the riverside in an urban Asian city. Very peaceful and serene.

Name: Pier 57
Description: Most people don't realize there's a free rooftop that closes at 1AM.

Name: Socrates Sculpture Park
Description: Right by the Noguchi Museum is a waterside park that has a rotation of various sculptures on display. Free!

Name: Cathedral of St. John the Divine
Description: There's a small garden the public can access inside the church grounds. Grab a pastry nearby and eat it here. Thanks Elika for introducing this spot!

Name: Fort Tryon
Description: The Heather Garden feels like a mini botanical garden - come here on a warm spring or summer day. Sometimes there's concerts hosted on the lawn as well.

Name: Wave Hill Public Garden
Description: You'll forget you're still in New York City. I love their lawn.

Name: The High Bridge
Description: The oldest bridge in the city. Grab some Domincan food on the Manhattan side while you're here.

Name: New York Botanical Garden
Description: I really enjoy the Azalea Garden in particular; every time I come I feel like a Disney princess because you'll be surrounded by birds, squirrels, and chipmunks.

Name: West Side Community Garden
Description: Small garden with seasonal plantings. Great place to stop by for a rest while in the UWS.

Name: 6BC Botanical Garden
Description: Treehouse, benches, and so many lovely plants. What more can one ask for?

Name: Whitney Museum
Description: Admission is free for anyone under 25! Contemporary American Art - I always enjoy seeing their rotating galleries.

Name: Salon 94
Description: TikTok has blown this place up but the gallery is still worth checking out.

Name: Neue Galerie
Description: They house some gorgeous works by Gustav Klimt. Admission prices are a bit steep given the size of the museum but they do have free admission days.

Name: Cooper Hewitt
Description: I really enjoyed their exhibit on concert set designs - I don't know if that was a temporary exhibition but their other stuff is also very interesting.

Name: Museum of the City of New York
Description: Learn about the history of New York City.

Name: The Met Cloisters
Description: I don't care for medieval art but I still would say this museum is something you cannot miss.

Name: PHILLIPS
Description: I wandered here with my coworker during our lunch break and they house a very significant collection of contemporary art pieces by famous artists. More niche stuff you'd find in private collections rather than museums.

Name: MoMA PS1
Description: Come here to experience a super neat James Turrell piece. Your life will be changed.

Name: The Noguchi Museum
Description: Very unique sculptures and you'll feel like you're in Japan.

Name: Brooklyn Museum
Description: The giant KAWS sculpture in the lobby made me laugh out loud ...

Name: The Museum at FIT
Description: I made a detour in the middle of a walk because the door said free entry. Cool exhibits on fashion.

Name: UBS Lobby
Description: I kept seeing ads on the subway for UBS's art collection accesible to the public - so I had to make my way there. Some interesting stuff; I think they rotate exhibits every few months or so.

Name: The Morgan Library & Museum
Description: Stunning library inside. You can't actually read the books sadly. They also have free jazz on Friday evenings.

Name: New York Transit Museum
Description: You don't even have to like trains that much to enjoy this museum. I honestly could've spent many hours here.

Name: Snug Harbor Cultural Center
Description: Part of the fun is riding the Staten Island Ferry to get here. Pretty gardens, although slightly unmaintained.

Name: African Burial Ground Visitor Center
Description: Barely anyone knows this place exists but everyone should come here to educate themselves.

Name: American Folk Art Museum
Description: Admission is free and they have cool pieces inside.

Name: Pratt Institute Sculpture Park
Description: I'm not sure how publicly accessible the campus is meant to be but I walked in with confidence and was able to get in. Their sculpture garden is gorgeous in the summer and fall and is shaded by large mature trees.

Name: Fort Greene Park
Description: I love the landscape and energy at Fort Greene Park - an undervisited gem in NYC.

Name: Dashwood Books
Description: Photobooks.

Name: Codex
Description: Used bookstore.

Name: Bonnie Slotnick Cookbooks
Description: Used cookbooks - many are antique.

Name: Mast Books
Description: Photobooks and harder-to-find titles.

Name: niconeco zakkaya
Description: Japanese stationary and cute cat-themed trinkets. I bought myself a pin of a cat pouring coffee.

Name: Casey Rubber Stamps
Description: Interior is in disarray, but is still fun to browse through the stamps they have out.

Name: Troubled Sleep
Description: Bookstore.

Name: Casa Magazines
Description: Big magazine stand - finally grabbed my copy of New York Review of Architecture here.

Name: Poster House
Description: Small but mighty museum filled with vintage/historical posters; great for graphic design enthusiasts.

Name: Word Community Bookshop
Description: Volunteer-run bookstore with great curation and a community-focused space. They have fentanyl testing strips available here as well.

Name: Hispanic Society Museum & Library
Description: Beautiful paintings inside by Joaquín Sorolla.

Name: Archestratus Books + Foods
Description: Cooking-themed books and miscellaneous food-themed merchandise.

Name: Cibone
Description: Expensive expensive interior goods from Japan. There's a collection of various stores and food vendors inside.

Name: Teak
Description: Also rather expensive Scandinavian home goods; I liked their dark green teddy couch a lot.

Name: Dream Fishing Tackle
Description: No longer a fishing store - this place now sells a curated selection of vintage home décor and there also is an expansive selection of records.

Name: Jefferson Market Garden
Description: Urban oasis tucked behind the Jefferson Market Library (another hidden gem!). I think their hours are limited but if the gate is open you must stop in.

Name: Left Bank Books
Description: Small bookstore with interesting selection.

Name: Society of Illustrators
Description: All things drawings! Cool art museum to kill an hour or two at.

Name: Argosy Bookstore
Description: I was in a hurry when I visited but they had a large selection of antique prints and vintage books. Great place to find unique wall décor.

Name: Rockaway Beach Surf Shop
Description: Surf shop selling a variety of comfy t-shirts.

Name: Dahing Plants
Description: Packed plant store with cute cats and affordable options.

Name: Swiss Institute
Description: I kept passing by on the bus so finallly had to stop by. True hidden gem in the East Village. Besides being a free art gallery, they also have a lovely rooftop and a small library you can work out of.

Name: The Drawing Center
Description: Free museum featuring various drawing exhibitions. Anna and I walked in on our way to Washington Square Park, our own hands filled with drawing materials.

Name: The New York Earth Room
Description: Dirt! In a room! Since 1977! Come here to be reconnected with Earth.

Name: Hudson River Park's River Project Wetlab
Description: Seasonal aquarium featuring various creatures that call the Hudson River home. You will surprised!

Name: Bruce's Garden
Description: Passed by on my way home from Inwood Park and took a pit stop inside. Super quaint community-maintained garden.

Name: Wing On Wo & Co
Description: Chinatown's oldest shop selling a variety of porcelain goods. Came here looking for Fu Dogs and was told they were out of stock.

Name: Culture Lab LIC
Description: Art gallery that doubles as a community center with lots of free music programming. They have jazz at sunset every Friday.

Name: Tend Greenpoint
Description: Plant store with adorable backyard.

Name: Albertine
Description: Beautiful French bookstore by the Met.

Name: Dia Chelsea
Description: Manhattan outpost of the Dia museum series. Free admission and rotating exhibits.

Name: Museum of the Moving Image
Description: Comprehensive museum of all things film and movie - with a special exhibit dedicated to the creator of The Muppets.

Name: Newtown HQ
Description: Store for all your cutesy trinkets.

Name: Lockwood
Description: Whimsical home goods and tchotkes; perfect place to buy a birthday present for people who don't know what they want.

Name: INCASA
Description: Higher-end home goods store.

Name: The New York Historical
Description: Their Tiffany Glass exhibit is a must-see and I declare it a gem of NYC.

Name: Amster Yard
Description: Quaint little courtyard tucked away in Midtown. Come here for some much-needed reprieve from the torment of corporate America.

Name: Friends NYC
Description: This is THE PLACE to get presents for the weed fiends in your life. They have the cutest and most whimsical bongs and pipes in stock.

Name: Father Duffy Square
Description: A less-crowded alternative to Greenacre park. Enjoy your lunch next to the sounds of a waterfall.

Name: Ford Foundation Atrium
Description: I'll admit this spot has been circulating within mainstream media but it's beautiful nonetheless. Lush indoor garden but the only downside is that there is no seating.
